qas.question: What percent of the previous population would a new digital transmitter have served in Fredicton in comparison to the analogue transmitter?
Was CBC's application for a digital transitter in Fredricton approved or rejected?
What did CBC say would allow broadcasting to continue?

answers.text: if the CRTC were to "allow CBC Television to continue providing the analogue service it offers today

qas.question: The CRTC required that all conversions serve at least what percent of the population?
The CRTC stated that it denied the application due to needing what?
The CBC planned to take the CRTC to court citing the superiority of this type of coverage?
The extreme wilderness forced the CRTC to make exceptions to the rule in what cities?

context: On March 23, 2011, the CRTC <a1_0>rejected<a1_0/> an application by the CBC to install a digital transmitter serving Fredricton, New Brunswick in place of the analogue transmitter serving Fredericton and Saint John, New Brunswick, which would have served only <a0_0><b3_0>62.5%<b3_0/><a0_0/> of the population served by the existing analogue transmitter. The CBC issued a press release stating "CBC/Radio-Canada intends to re-file its application with the CRTC to provide <b4_0>more detailed cost estimates<b4_0/> that will allow the Commission to better understand the unfeasibility of replicating the Corporation’s current analogue coverage." The press release further added that the CBC suggests coverage could be maintained <a2_0>if the CRTC were to "allow CBC Television to continue providing the <b5_0>analogue service<b5_0/> it offers today<a2_0/> – much in the same way the Commission permitted recently in the case of <b6_0>Yellowknife, Whitehorse and Iqaluit.<b6_0/>"
